column3063: Oh, what's the use of that?
column3066: And there's no second innings in life.
column3069: Don't the people need you just as much as ever?
column3071: The people have no use for broken idols, Denis.
column3082: I always thought you'd the wrong temperament for Parliament.
column3084: You knew me for the rotten failure that I am.
column3085: I congratulate you on your perspicacity.
column3089: What do you propose to do?
column3091: I don't propose to do anything.
column3094: I'm a man with a past, an ex-M.P., ex-Everything.
column3103: I'm only saying it to rouse you.
column3105: You'll say nothing that I won't agree with.
column3108: You've a big future before you.
column3114: I'm going to take it lying down, Denis, and that's all there is to it.
column3116: That's a pretty mean thing to say, Peter.
column3118: Oh, taunts don't sting me now.
column3119: I've reached the further side of agony.
column3121: (_sitting at table, centre, leaning on it very close to Peter, and speaking without a trace of sympathy_).
column3122: Peter, don't you think you've made sufficient demonstration of your grief?
column3128: That's what you wanted, wasn't it?
column3129: (_Peter meets her eye questioningly._) To prove to yourself that after all you're still of consequence to somebody.
column3131: We're not content to watch you sulk to death.
column3133: For a week you've had the joy of fostering your wound, keeping it open for all the world to see how hardly you've been hit, but it's time you healed it now.
column3134: Peter (_hiding his head on the table_).
column3138: (_Rising and tapping the table._) Or found out, Peter?
column3140: Peter (_pitiably turning, still sitting, to Mrs. Garside_).
column3141: Mother, you let these people in.
column3142: Are you going to sit there and let them bully a sick man?
column3146: The great, strong, self-willed man brought down to crying to his mammie.
column3151: I promised Margaret her own way.
column3154: Besides, I think there may be something in it.
column3155: [_Peter hides his face again with a deep "Oh!
column3160: Yes, it's all very well for you to talk.
column3161: You with your beastly robust health.
column3164: I assure you, you're not looking half so feeble as you did.
column3167: Then I must thrive on torture.
column3170: You're not the woebegone catastrophe you were.
column3174: You prefer to be a catastrophe, in fact?
column3176: I want to be left alone.
column3180: Oh, you'll not escape that way.
column3181: I don't in the least mind invading your bedroom.
column3189: Fresh air will do you good.
column3192: They'll mock me in the streets.
column3196: Peter (_sitting centre, behind table, covering face_).
column3197: I'll close my eyes and stop my ears.
column3201: (_She puts her hat on the bookcase and her fur on it._) Peter (_turning and watching her_).
column3203: So it's to be a trial of strength, is it?
column3206: As I'm strong and you're weak, I ought to win.
column3210: Of course, I've only your word for it.
column3211: [_Margaret takes chair from wall, right, and puts it before fire._ Peter.
